diagrams.description: Robotics engineering history began in the 1920s with Karel Čapek introducing the term robot in his play R.U.R. The 1950s saw the first programmable robot (Unimate) and Isaac Asimov's Three Laws of Robotics. 1961 marked Unimate's deployment in a GM factory, starting industrial robotics. The 1970s brought Stanford Cart and early mobile robots with computer vision. 1980s witnessed SCARA robots and enhanced manufacturing automation. 1997 introduced Mars Pathfinder's Sojourner rover and Honda's ASIMO humanoid development. The 2000s saw autonomous vehicles (DARPA Grand Challenge 2004), commercial drones, and surgical robots (da Vinci). The 2010s advanced collaborative robots (cobots), AI integration, and Boston Dynamics' dynamic robots. The 2020s continue with autonomous delivery systems, soft robotics, and human-robot collaboration becoming mainstream.

timeline
    title The History of Robotics
    section Early Concepts & Automata
        1495 : Leonardo da Vinci's mechanical knight
        1921 : The term "robot" is coined in Karel Čapek's play "R.U.R."
        1942 : Isaac Asimov's "Three Laws of Robotics"
    section The First Industrial Robots
        1954 : George Devol patents the first programmable robot, "Unimate"
        1961 : Unimate is installed on a General Motors assembly line
        1978 : The PUMA (Programmable Universal Machine for Assembly) arm is developed
    section The 1980s-1990s: Mobile and Autonomous Robots
        1980s : Growth in research on mobile robots
        1997 : The Sojourner rover lands on Mars
    section The 2000s: The Robotic Revolution
        2000 : Honda's ASIMO humanoid robot
        2002 : iRobot's Roomba vacuum cleaner
        2005 : Stanley, a self-driving car, wins the DARPA Grand Challenge
    section The 2010s: AI and Collaboration
        2010s : Rise of collaborative robots (cobots)
        2010s : Deep learning revolutionizes robot vision and control
